Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Community Dynamics in a Traditional Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cultural developments of the last 10,000 years have involved two critical transitions in human lifeways: the emergence of the first settled villages and the development of complex societies which characterize modern life. Patrick Dolan, with the support of the National Science Foundation and under the guidance of Dr. Colin Grier at Washington State University, will conduct fieldwork at the Dionisio Point site a prehistoric hunter-gatherer village on the coast of British Columbia, Canada. This village was occupied at a time when the inhabitants of this region achieved levels of social complexity rarely witnessed outside of agricultural societies, providing an important counter-balance to explanations of social complexity as a consequence of the emergence of food production.

In coastal southwestern British Columbia, Canada, the emergence of settled plankhouse villages between 2500 and 1000 years ago corresponds to a period of increasingly demarcated social status, wealth, and eventually greater warfare. Archaeological research in this and the surrounding region indicates that the emergence and organization of large multi-family households were critical in the unfolding of these cultural developments. However, due to a shortage of empirical data, the social and economic articulations between households within a village remain uncertain. Were villages cohesive collective socially and economically? Were they organized from the top-down around the demands of powerful households? Or were households relatively autonomous of one another, pursuing their own goals on a regional stage? Few settlements dating to this period have been sampled in a manner that permits the evaluation of these alternatives, and this research will fill this gap in knowledge.

This project will be one of the first to systematically examine these questions within a single village in southwestern British Columbia. The fieldwork component of this research will be conducted at the Dionisio Point site, a multi-household, Coast Salish village occupied between 1500 and 1300 years ago on Galiano Island in coastal southwestern British Columbia, Canada. Evaluating the structure of inter-household economic relations in this village will require refining the occupational history for the village at Dionisio Point as well as characterizing long-term household production and consumption practices. Using excavated materials collected from household architecture and refuse deposits associated with each of the five houses at the site, this project will recover materials that will permit radiocarbon dating, as well as the comparison of the remains of the fauna households consumed, the tools they used, and their respective storage capacities.

This research promotes collaboration between researchers in the USA and Canada, as well as a greater appreciation of the value of prehistory to the public and of the cultural heritage of local First Nations peoples. This project will contribute to the professional development of graduate students in both field methods and laboratory analyses. Results will be disseminated widely in academic circles through professional publications, and to the public through talks and newsletters. Ultimately, this project will promote continued engagement of academic archaeologists with descendent communities and the Galiano Island resident community, fostering improved collaboration in the preservation of the cultural heritage of this region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social inequality is intrinsic in the organization of modern states and pervasive in the institutions and values through which we engage in day-to-day life. Yet, it is not an essential property of human society. Ethnographic research over the last century has revealed our capacity to mitigate if not entirely silence social difference, confirming what anthropologists have long recognized--that social inequality is an historical phenomenon. Archaeology is at the forefront of cross-cultural research into the development of inequality in the social sciences. Its uniquely long-term historical perspective provides an unparalleled opportunity to document how and why some people decide to, or are coerced into, forfeiting their personal autonomy.

The subject of this project is the early unfolding of these processes among the societies of the Salish Sea on the border between Washington State and British Columbia, Canada. At the time of Euro-American Contact, these societies were socially complex. There were real differences in wealth, prestige, and status. They produced elaborate truly monumental works of art in houses, poles, and canoes. And yet, for all this there are little widely accepted post-Contact evidence of political or economic centralization. This project tests the hypothesis that political and economic decentralization was characteristic of early villages in the region.

The Dionisio Point site is an early village on the northern coast of Galiano Island, British Columbia, Canada. At its height 1,600 years ago, it was occupied by as many as 150 people living in five enormous wooden post-and-beam houses from the late fall through the spring. This was a time of social transformation in the region. Increased trade, warfare, wealth accumulation, and status differentiation created long-distance social networks across the region, while, locally, social differences became more pronounced. Excavations at Dionisio Point are the first to tell us whether households engaged in this changes collectively, as a village, or autonomously, as independent groups.

Washington State University researchers directed two seasons of excavation at Dionisio Point to answer these questions. Field crews targeted refuse deposits associated with each of the five houses in the village. Sampling outdoor refuse rather than indoor floor deposits allows us to control for the spatial complexity of indoor behaviours and ensure that comparison of the samples is valid. The result was the excavation of more than three cubic metres of refuse for each of the five houses in the village. It is the first time that archaeologists have a sample of materials from an entire village.

These excavations generated more than 100 artifacts, thousands of faunal remains, and fourteen new radiocarbon dates, affording archaeologists an unprecedented opportunity to study the formation and organization of a village of this antiquity. They also presented a rare opportunity to train students in the scientific investigation of a pre-Contact village. WSU graduate and undergraduate students were engaged at every stage of the research project, from excavation to laboratory analysis and interpretation.

The village was established during the third century AD, but attained its final form after it underwent a period of rapid growth almost a century later. Households were economically organized to procure a range of food and non-food resources from a variety of environments, relying upon cooperation and collaboration within the household to meet dietary and social demands on their production. Slight variation between food items and tools recovered from each of the houses reveals that they were not engaged in exactly the same activities--that they were not organized into a single collective village.
